Try-me¶

This notebooks demonstrates a few features of the PAVICS platform. We’re using Birdy’s WPSClient to call WPS processes directly from Python. To get the list of processes, simply type fp. then tab, and a drop down menu will pop-up showing the different processes that are available. To get information on the process and how to call it, simply type help(fp.<name of process>) or fp.<name of process>? followed by CTRL-Enter. In other words, the WPSClient exposes remote processes as if they were part of a normal python library.

Note that his uses the bleeding edge version of owslib (github master) since some issues were found and fixed in the process of writing this notebook.

Spatial and temporal subsetting¶

A common task in climate data analysis is subsetting files over a region of interest. Global model simulations and observations cover the entire globe, while impact analyses are often concerned with a region. Instead of downloading the entire file on a local disk, it is often more practical to subset it on the server and only download the relevant part.

This can be done through two ways: interactive analysis using OPeNDAP, or a WPS request for a subsetter. Let’s start with the most direct approach with OPeNDAP. The PAVICS THREDDS server provides two links for each file, a link to the file itself which will download the file locally when accessed, and a dodsC link which supports the OPeNDAP protocol. We’ll use this link and simply pass it to our netCDF library, here xarray.

In [49]:

import xarray as xr
import numpy as np
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
# The dodsC link for the test file
dap = 'https://pavics.ouranos.ca/twitcher/ows/proxy/thredds/dodsC/'
ncfile = 'birdhouse/testdata/flyingpigeon/cmip5/tasmax_Amon_MPI-ESM-MR_rcp45_r1i1p1_200601-200612.nc'

# Here we open the file and subset it using xarray fonctionality.
ds = xr.open_dataset(dap+ncfile)
tas = ds.tasmax
subtas = tas.sel(time=slice('2006-01-01', '2006-03-01'), lon=slice(188,330), lat=slice(6, 70))
subtas.isel(time=0).plot()

Out[49]:

<matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh at 0x7f6d0d71e898>

Now we’re going to compute the min and max of the array and use this for the next example.

In [50]:

mn, mx = subtas.min().values.tolist(), subtas.max().values.tolist()
mn, mx

Out[50]:

(239.8588409423828, 308.3053894042969)

Gridded Data Renderer¶

PAVICS uses ncWMS2 to render netCDF data on a map canvas. ncWMS2 use the OGC’s WMS standard to serve images rendered from a netCDF file. The WMS GetMap operation specifies a layer (/), styles, figure size and format, projection and color range and the server returns an image that can be displayed in a figure or a map canvas.

Note that with the current configuration, the path for ncWMS layers starts with outputs and not birdhouse as in the THREDDS server. Note also that the image we obtain below is upside down compared to the one above.

In [59]:

from owslib.wms import WebMapService
from IPython.display import Image

url = "https://pavics.ouranos.ca/twitcher/ows/proxy/ncWMS2/wms"
wms = WebMapService(url, version='1.3.0')
ncfile = 'outputs/testdata/flyingpigeon/cmip5/tasmax_Amon_MPI-ESM-MR_rcp45_r1i1p1_200601-200612.nc'
resp = wms.getmap(
          layers=["{}/{}".format(ncfile, "tasmax")],
          format='image/png',
          colorscalerange='{},{}'.format(mn,mx),
          size=[256,256],
          srs='CRS:84',
          bbox=(150, 30, 250, 80),
          transparent=True)
Image(resp.read())

Out[59]:

Climate indices¶

The current production version of PAVICS provides ICCLIM indices through the FlyingPigeon server, which includes over fourty different indices. In the example below, we’re calling on the

Another implementation of climate indices is in the works. It relies on the xarray+dask backend to parallelize computations in the background. The library of climate indices is xclim and the WPS server hosting it is finch.

In [62]:

from birdy import WPSClient
url = 'https://pavics.ouranos.ca/twitcher/ows/proxy/flyingpigeon/wps'
fp = WPSClient(url)

resp = fp.icclim_tx(resource=thredds+'cmip3/tas.sresb1.giss_model_e_r.run1.atm.da.nc', grouping='yr')

Bias correction¶

There is at the moment only one bias correction process implemented, the Kernel Density Distribution Mapping. It was written in R and given an observation variable obs, a simulated variable over the observation period ref and a future period fut, it would be called as fp.kddm_bc(obs=obs, ref=ref, fut=fut). Since this function is so compute intensive, we’ll create a small synthetic file for testing.

Note¶

The current production version of FlyingPigeon runs on a version of PyWPS whose handling of binary files is sketchy. That means that it works well when files are provided as references, not embedded in an http request. This functionality will become available with the next update. For this example we’ll use files stored on the PAVICS THREDDS server.

In [9]:

thredds = 'https://pavics.ouranos.ca/twitcher/ows/proxy/thredds/fileServer/birdhouse/testdata/flyingpigeon/'

obs = thredds + 'tmax.obs.nc'
ref = thredds + 'tmax.cur.nc'
fut = thredds + 'tmax.fut.nc'

resp = fp.kddm_bc(obs=obs, ref=ref, fut=fut)
resp

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

      6
----> 7 resp = fp.kddm_bc(obs=obs, ref=ref, fut=fut)

NameError: name 'fp' is not defined

The response is a link to the bias-corrected file. It’s possible to get the actual netCDF file by using the get method of the response.

In [8]:

tx

Out[8]:

icclim_TXResponse(
    output_netcdf='https://pavics.ouranos.ca:443/wpsoutputs/flyingpigeon/de46db5a-1441-11e9-888f-0242ac120014/de698fec-1441-11e9-888f-0242ac120014_TUFzax.nc',
    output_log='https://pavics.ouranos.ca:443/wpsoutputs/flyingpigeon/de46db5a-1441-11e9-888f-0242ac120014/log_eyxZgY.txt'
)

In [13]:

Subset processes with WPS and FlyingPigeon¶

PAVICS offers a number of subsetting processes: - subset_continents - subset_countries - subset_bbox - subset_wfs - subset

The subset_continents and subset_countries use a predefined list of polygons for the subsetting. The subset_bbox takes the geographical coordinates of the two opposite corner of a rectangle to define the subset region, while both subset_wfs and subset use a polygon defined on a remote geoserver, identified by a typename and a feature id. The only difference is that subset also does temporal subsetting.

In [9]:


afr = fp.subset_continents(resource=thredds+res, region='Africa')

In [26]:

mex = fp.subset_countries(resource=thredds+res, region='FRA')
